titleStmt.title: Peace and Dunkirk;
BEING AN
Excellent New Song upon the Surren-
der of Dunkirk to General Hill.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: To the Tune of, The King shall enjoy His own again.

SPIGHT of Dutch Friends and English Foes,Great Britain shall have Peace at last;Holland got Towns, and we got Blows,But Dunkirk's Ours, we'll hold it fast:We have got it in a String,And the Whigs may all go Swing,
For among good Friends, I love to be plain;All their false-deluded Hopes,Will, or ought, to end in Ropes;For the QUEEN has enjoy'd Her own again.II.

Sunder------d's run out of his Wits,And Dismal double-Dismal looks;Whar--n can only Swear by Fits,And strutting Hal----x is off the Hooks,Old Godol-----n full of Spleen,Made false Moves, and lost his QUEEN;Harry look'd fierce, and shook his ragged Mane;But a Prince of high Renown,Swore he'd rather lose a Crown,QUEEN should enjoy Her own again.III.
Our Merchant Ships may cut the Line, And not be snapt by Privateers,
And Commoners who love good Wine,Will drink it now as well as Peers:Landed-Men shall have their Rent,Yet our Stocks rise Cent. per Cent,
The Dutch from hence shall no more Millions drain;We'll bring on us no more Debts,Nor with Bankrupts fill Gazetts,QUEEN has enjoy'd Her own again.IV.
The Towns we took ne'er did us good: What signify't the French to beat?
We spent our Money and our Blood,To make the Dutch-men proud and great:But the Lord of Oxford Swears,Dunkirk never shall be theirs,
The Dutch-hearted Whigs may rail and complain,But true British Men will fill,A good Health to Gen'ral Hill,QUEEN now enjoys Her own again.168-12A3
